title: Nishant Panicker
text:
I am a PhD student in Integrative Systems Biology at the University of Pittsburgh. My research lives at the intersection of microbiology, genomics and high-throughput data analysis, where I work on decrypting the chemical interactions between soil bacteria.
Beyond the lab, my life is defined by the the Indian classical arts. I am a trained Hindustani Classical Musician and Kathak Dancer, and I believe that the boundaries between disciplines are fading—whether in science or art.



Research: Deciphering patterns in mass spectrometry data indicative of microbial interactions.
Music & Dance: Exploring the intricacies of India’s ancient traditions and their modern-day relevance.
Hobbies: Cooking, running, meditating, and spending time on the beach.

title: Music
text:
I was initiated into the world of Hindustani classical music at the age of 6. After initial training under Shri Anant Heggar Hegde, I was fortunate to receive vocal training and early inspiration from the late sarod maestro Pt. Rajeev Taranath. When I was 11, Pandit ji moved cities and entrusted me to Vidushi Lalith J. Rao, doyenne of the Agra-Atrauli gharana. Over the last 17 years, under Lalith ji’s caring, encouraging and astute guidance, I have continued my journey in music, exploring the vastness and intricacies of the Agra-Atrauli tradition.

title: Research
text:
Research Focus
My work revolves around decrypting how soil microorganisms communicate through a wide variety of small molecules. This chemical language is essential for understanding their functional roles and ecological dynamics.
I utilize a 3D printed platform and high-throughput mass spectrometry to eavesdrop on interactions between pairs of bacterial strains. This allows me to infer the context-specific language of microbial communication for a large panel of soil bacteria.
